column5: I think it would serve you well to read (and think critically and deeply) about what progressivism is as an intellectual outlook and how it shapes your views on ‚Äúhuman knowledge.‚Äù

For me it‚Äôs not so much about believing. It‚Äôs the recognition that ancient texts are the only primary source we have on the history of humanity. The stories, songs, and philisophical ruminations contained within them are the best tools we have to understand, in a transcendental way, what our lives actually mean in the grand scheme of things. I just trust that there is wisdom to be had in reading them and taking them into serious consideration. My focus is on the Bible because that‚Äôs my ethnic heritage. It makes me feel like a complete human being, rather than an animal.

Archeologists, anthropologists, etc, are just speculators. I believed in evolution and all that hook line and sinker until I saw the bones with my own eyes. They have nothing. In the West they say human beings emerged in the middle east, in China they say we came from the far east. It‚Äôs a confidence game. They call it science, but it isn‚Äôt. The only thing I‚Äôve become convinced of by studying it is that human history probably goes back twice as long as they say it does which coincides directly with my interpretation of Genisis.

I‚Äôve studied archeology and anthropology at the university level. I‚Äôve written and read many academic papers on the deep past. It‚Äôs all bullshit. You have ancient scriptures and you have blowhard narcissists who speculate about the origins of things. It‚Äôs not a choice between a 2000 year old book and logic. For me at least, it‚Äôs a choice to either listen to voices of the past and try to derive some meaning from from them, or it is to view myself as nothing but an animal frantically trying to reproduce before I die. I choose to turn my back to the Abyss.

Based on what you‚Äôve said, your conclusion makes sense. I‚Äôve experienced similar things, and I have a similar personality. I recommend the book CPTSD: From Surviving to Thriving by Pete Walker. I know a book recommendation is a tough sell because everybody has one, but I‚Äôm not fucking with you, this book is a MUST READ. It‚Äôs short and easy to digest. Order it ASAP and start your healing journey. Best of luck my friend.

When I graduated from college in 2015 I sent out applications and did interviews for months. Eventually I went broke and started delivering sandwiches to the same offices I had tried to get a job in. I lived in a state capital at the time and had a degree in economics and public administration. But ironically I couldn‚Äôt even get an internship. It was a difficult period of my life, and it made me bitter for awhile. Luckily, I was able to regroup, financially and emotionally, and get on a different professional path. But I had to totally sacrifice my 20s to the god of money to get it done. I don‚Äôt have a single friend left. All I care about is working because I‚Äôm so scared of being broke again.

I (28 M) have Asperger‚Äôs, and I can relate. Having no friends and being unable to connect with women has led to substance abuse problems, lonliness, and severe depression. There are five things that help me deal with all this.

1) Running - it improves my mental functioning dramatically. Lifting weights helps as well, but not as much.

2) Medication - this should be number 1. See a psychiatrist for depression if you feel hopeless. That‚Äôs what they‚Äôre for. I take medication every day.

3) Being Good at Something - I felt suicidal from the ages of 19 and 24 because of my autism. But then I started seriously working on my career. I got good at something that I chose myself and made a career out of it.

Corroboration - https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=r8uhcRK1QKU

4) Manning Up and Taking Responsibility for Myself - I‚Äôm going to be brutally honest about something. He shouldn‚Äôt be talking about his sex life with you, autism or no autism. He needs to be just actively solving problems on his own. Anything from taking a class, to joining a club, to seeking out social skills training, if he wants to improve he has to work at it.

5) Having Perspective - Plenty of people struggle with isolation and lonliness for different reasons. Look at all the comments. This is a common and manageable problem. It‚Äôs not the end of the world. He can overcome his internal and external challenges. He is stronger than he realizes.

TLDR: Depression can be managed, and he can improve. It‚Äôs not the end of the world.

When I say regular people I mean families where the individuals earn average incomes, ‚Äúnew money‚Äù families, or families with one or two college-educated sets of kids. I come from a family like this. 

My grandfather was an orphan and died owning his own house. My own father passed down that virtue of self reliance, and he didn‚Äôt hold my hand financially when I became an adult even though he‚Äôs a doctor and could afford to help me. I had to make it on my own. 

Many people who struggle in America are looking for opportunities rather than special help or sympathy. They don‚Äôt enjoy being looked at as victims or as unsophistacted fools who need to be taken care of.

I didn‚Äôt know this, and have two thoughts about it.

* It seems ironic because we don‚Äôt consider those brands to be premium. They‚Äôre not bad by any means. They‚Äôre trusted. But they are considered average quality.

* The second though I have as a student of economics is that they MUST be marketed this way. Extending their distribution into your market is risky and expensive. To cover their costs and to make serving the Indian market profitable, they have to show that they‚Äôre special.

The lock down has almost ruined me. I‚Äôm barely hanging on without any friends or family. I used to go out in public and go to random community events and support groups when I was lonely. Now I have no one. I‚Äôm really not ok. I have a feeling of impending doom constantly.
Yeah, I really do. But there‚Äôs some good in this world, Mr. Frodo. And it‚Äôs worth fightin‚Äô for.

I forgot to mention the other thing I‚Äôve learned. I‚Äôve spent hundreds of dollars on fancy safes. And regretably, I roped in two family members to safeguard my meds at times. But in the long run, I realized that it‚Äôs  really important for me to call the shots with my medication. The only person I speak to about it is my psychiatrist. I pay her to play a responsible role, and I believe she can be compassionate and objective.

Like I said, I‚Äôve been there. I‚Äôve gotten myself scared and freaked out my family. It takes time to unwind that kind of scenario and reestablish boundaries, but it can be done. And I think that would be helpful for you going forward.

This is my opinion after years of experience with this kind of thing. American/western culture just has a repressive and backwards attitude toward drugs. Putting your brain in the meatgrinder trying to decide if you‚Äôre a real addict or not is not helpful. I think addiction is really a myth altogether, but that‚Äôs a side issue. If the drugs are helping you, keep taking them. If they‚Äôre not, change the dose, maybe to zero. If you took some drugs for fun, that‚Äôs not so bad. You‚Äôll be fine. Just realize you‚Äôre not alone and you‚Äôll be ok. Don‚Äôt catastrophize.
